5110.Description: An unreinforced masonry construction type composed of two layers of bricks, common in many cities in Australia.

5150.Name: Concrete, Reinforced concrete
5150.Description: Reinforced concrete buildings consist of reinforced concrete columns and beams. Use this if the other technical characteristics of the building are unknown.

5151.Name: Concrete, Reinforced concrete shear wall w/ mrf
5151.Description: Building constructed with reinforced concrete columns and beams, as well as reinforced concrete floor and roof. "Moment Resisting Frames" carry lateral loads by bending. "Shear Walls" are continuous reinforced concrete extending from the foundation to the roof and can be exterior walls or interior walls.

5152.Name: Concrete, Reinforced concrete shear wall w/o mrf
5152.Description: Building constructed with reinforced concrete columns and beams, as well as reinforced concrete floor and roof. Reinforced concrete Shear Walls are continuous reinforced concrete, extending from the foundation to the roof and can be exterior walls or interior walls. This category typically consists of buildings with a concrete box structural system with shear walls. The entire structure, along with the usual concrete diaphragm, is typically cast in place.

5153.Name: Concrete, Reinforced concrete mrf ductile
5153.Description: Buildings constructed with reinforced concrete columns, beams, and slabs. Moment Resisting Frames carry lateral loads due to earthquakes by bending. This kind of structural system can sustain large deformations and absorb energy without brittle failure.

5154.Name: Concrete, Reinforced concrete mrf non-ductile
5154.Description: Buildings constructed with reinforced concrete columns, beams, and slabs. Moment Resisting Frames carry lateral loads due to earthquakes by bending. These structures have insufficient reinforcing steel embedded in the concrete and thus display low ductility.

5155.Name: Concrete, Tilt-up
5155.Description: Tilt-up buildings are constructed with reinforced concrete wall panels that are cast on the ground and then tilted upward into their final positions. These wall units are then anchored to the foundation and attached to each other. The roof and floor decks are typically wood. More recently, the wall panels are fabricated off-site and trucked in. These buildings tend to be one or two stories in height.

5156.Name: Concrete, Pre-cast concrete
5156.Description: The pre-cast frame is essentially a post and beam system in concrete in which columns, beams, and slabs are prefabricated and assembled on site.

5157.Name: Concrete, Pre-cast concrete w/ shear wall
5157.Description: The pre-cast frame is essentially a post and beam system in concrete in which columns, beams, and slabs are prefabricated and assembled on site. Lateral loads due to earthquakes are carried by cast-in-place concrete "shear" walls.

5158.Name: Concrete, Reinforced concrete mrf
5158.Description: A building constructed with reinforced concrete columns, beams, and slabs. "Moment-resisting frames" carry lateral loads due to earthquakes by bending. Information on the reinforcing steels is not sufficient to determine the building level of ductility.

5159.Name: Concrete, Reinforced concrete mrf with URM
5159.Description: Reinforced concrete columns and beams form "moment-resisting frames" to carry lateral loads due to earthquakes. Unreinforced masonry walls are used as infills between the columns to add lateral load resistance, but are not intended to serve as gravity load-bearing elements.

5200.Name: Steel, Steel
5200.Description: Steel frame buildings consist of steel columns and beams. Use this if the other technical characteristics of the building are unknown.

5201.Name: Steel, Light metal
5201.Description: Light metal buildings are made of light gauge steel frame and are usually clad with lightweight metal or asbestos siding and roof, often corrugated. They typically are low-rise structures.

5202.Name: Steel, Braced steel frame
5202.Description: Buildings constructed with steel columns and beams that are braced with diagonal steel members to resist lateral forces.

5203.Name: Steel, Steel mrf perimeter
5203.Description: Buildings constructed with steel columns and beams that are braced with diagonal steel members to resist lateral forces.

5204.Name: Steel, Steel mrf distributed
5204.Description: Buildings constructed with steel columns and beams to carry lateral loads distributed throughout the building. The diaphragms are usually concrete, sometimes over steel decking. This structural type is seldom used for low-rise buildings.

5205.Name: Steel, Steel mrf
5205.Description: Steel MRF buildings consist of structural steel columns and beams. Lateral loads due to earthquakes are carried by the "moment-resisting frames," but the locations of the moment-resisting frames in the building are unknown.

5206.Name: Steel, Steel frame w/ URM
5206.Description: Structural steel columns and beams form "moment-resisting frames" to carry lateral loads due to earthquakes. Unreinforced masonry walls are used as infills between the columns to add lateral load resistance, but are not intended to serve as vertical load-bearing elements. Sometimes the steel frames are completely hidden in the masonry walls.

5207.Name: Steel, Steel frame w/ concrete shear wall
5207.Description: Structural steel columns and beams form exterior frames, but the joints are not designed for moment resistance. Lateral loads due to earthquakes are carried by reinforced concrete "shear" walls. The concrete walls are continuous from the foundation to the roof.

5208.Name: Steel, Steel reinforced concrete
5208.Description: Structural steel sections (beams and columns) are encased in reinforced concrete. The encased structural steel columns are sometimes discontinued in the upper portions of the buildings, making the columns in the upper floor regular reinforced concrete columns.

5209.Name: Steel, Steel long span
5209.Description: Steel long-span buildings create unobstructed, column-free spaces greater than 100 feet for a variety of activities or functions. These include activities where visibility is important for large audiences (e.g., auditoriums and covered stadiums), where flexibility is important (e.g., exhibition halls and certain types of manufacturing facilities), and where large movable objects are housed. Two-hinge (made of a single member hinged at each end) and three-hinge (made of two members hinged at each end and at the meeting point at the crown) trussed arches are widely used.

5251.Name: Composite, FM – Fire res RC Apt. Masonry dwellings
5251.Description: New residential fire code; concrete, concrete block, masonry, stone, fire-resistant dwellings.

5252.Name: Composite, FT – Fire res non-apt dwl RC mas/stl
5252.Description: New residential fire code; steel, semi-fire-resistant.

5253.Name: Composite, FH – Dwellings other than FM, FT
5253.Description: New residential fire code; other dwellings.

5254.Name: Composite, F1 – Fire res RC and masonry bldg
5254.Description: New commercial fire code; concrete, concrete block, masonry, stone, fire-resistant dwellings.

5255.Name: Composite, F2 – Semi-fire res and steel bldg
5255.Description: New commercial fire code; steel, semi-fire-resistant.

5256.Name: Composite, F3 – Buildings other than F1,F2
5256.Description: New commercial fire code; other dwellings.

5257.Name: Composite, A: Fire-resistive dwellings
5257.Description: Main structure (column, beam, and floor) is constructed of concrete or steel covered with noncombustible material. Roof and external walls are built using nonflammable material.

5258.Name: Composite, B: Semi-fire-resistive dwellings
5258.Description: (1) External walls consist of any one of the following: concrete, concrete material, brick or stone masonry. (2) Steel structure with external walls of nonflammable material or covered with noncombustible material.

5259.Name: Composite, C: Slow-burning dwellings
5259.Description: (1) Wood frame with external walls of any of the following: cement or mortar plating, stone pitching or tile hinging. (2) Steel structure that does not come under Class B. Excluding building with external walls of boarding and/or synthetic resin hanging and/or cloth hanging.

5260.Name: Composite, D: Dwelling other than A, B or C
5260.Description: Building other than Class A, B, and C.

5261.Name: Composite, Sp: Fire-resistive concrete buildings
5261.Description: Main structure (column, beam, and floor) is constructed of concrete and all external walls are of any one of the following: concrete, concrete material, brick, or stone masonry.

5262.Name: Composite, 1: Fire-resistive buildings other
5262.Description: (1) Main structure (column, beam, and floor) is constructed of concrete or steel covered with noncombustible material. Roof and external walls are built using nonflammable material. (2) Main structure (column, beam, and floor) is constructed of wood and/or steel covered with noncombustible material. Roof and external walls are built of or covered by nonflammable and/or semi-nonflammable material. Column, beam, floor, and external walls are to be resistant against the heat under normal fire conditions for at least 1 hour.

5263.Name: Composite, 2: Semi-fire-resistive buildings
5263.Description: (1) External walls consist of any one of the following: concrete / concrete block / brick / stone masonry. (2) Steel structure with external walls of nonflammable and/or semi-nonflammable material or covered with noncombustible material. (3) Main structure (column, beam, and floor) is constructed of wood and/or steel covered with noncombustible material. Roof and external walls consist of or are covered by nonflammable and/or semi-nonflammable materials. Column, beam, floor, and external walls to be resistant against the heat under normal fire conditions for at least 45 minutes.

5264.Name: Composite, 3: Slow-burning buildings
5264.Description: (1) Wood frame (and not applicable to Class 1 or 2) with external walls of nonflammable and/or semi-nonflammable material or covered with noncombustible material. (2) Steel structure that does not come under Class 1 or 2. Excluding building with external walls of boarding and/or synthetic resin hanging and/or cloth hanging.

5265.Name: Composite, 4: Other than Sp, 1, 2, or 3
5265.Description: Buildings other than Class SP, 1, 2, and 3.

5301.Name: Special, Long-span
5301.Description: Building constructed with steel frame and metal siding and roof of wood or other combustible material. Typically gymnasiums or auditoriums.

5302.Name: Special, Semi-wind resistive
5302.Description: A building for which a licensed engineer does not design the structure, but an attempt is made to build in accordance with an accepted wind building code; code compliance is not assured. Some engineering input may have occurred. Most of the details in a wind resistive structure are found in a semi-wind resistive structure, but not all components are wind resistive.

5303.Name: Special, Wind resistive
5303.Description: A structure that was designed by a licensed engineer to comply with the wind code. Characterized by the presence of properly sized wind-resistant connectors, adequate bracing, and a continuous load path from the roof to the foundation (i.e., the roof is tied to the walls, the floors are attached to each other, and the walls are tied to the foundation).

5304.Name: Special, Unknown glass
5304.Description: Code for the U.S. Hurricane Plate Glass Module when the type of glass is unknown

5305.Name: Special, Safety glass
5305.Description: Safety glass includes fully tempered and laminated glass. Fully tempered glass is created by heating common annealed glass uniformly to make a high-strengthened glass. Laminated glass is made by sandwiching a plastic sheet between two glass panels, which prevents shattering and helps maintains the integrity of the building envelop even after its breakage.

5306.Name: Special, Impact resistance glass
5306.Description: Impact-resistant glass similar to laminated glass (as described above), which has been tested to resist breakage from flying debris during hurricanes. Impact-resistant glass is typically thicker than safety glass and is packaged as a unit that includes a special frame.

5309.Name: Special, Basement Flood Loss - High Value
5309.Description: Buildings with high-value equipment stored in the basement such as subways and other buildings with generators located in the basement etc. which are very sensitive to flood.

5310.Name: Special, Flood Resistance General
5310.Description: Buildings in general, designed and built with good flooding resistances, excluding bridges, dams and water tower having minimal flood damage

5350.Name: Mobile Homes, Mobile Homes
5350.Description: Represents a weighted average of tie-down types, including no tie-downs. Use this code for a mobile home (manufactured home) when the tie-down information is unknown.

5351.Name: Mobile Homes, Mobile homes no tie down
5351.Description: Use this code for a mobile home (manufactured home) with no anchoring systems present.

5352.Name: Mobile Homes, Mobile homes part tie down
5352.Description: Use this code for a mobile home (manufactured home) when the tie-downs are either over-the-top ties or frame ties, but not both, or with fewer ties than recommended by the manufacturer.

5353.Name: Mobile Homes, Mobile homes full tie down
5353.Description: Use this code for a mobile home (manufactured home) when the anchoring system uses both over-the-top ties and frame ties. Typically, ten frame ties and seven over-the-top ties are required for full tie-down in single-wide mobile homes.

5354.Name: Mobile Homes, Double Wide
5354.Description: Same as Mobile homes tied down but having double width living unit and in general more wind resistive

5400.Name: Bridges, Unknown Bridge
5400.Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges with individual span length less than 500 feet with unknown material of construction, unknown number of spans, and unknown support conditions, or other unknown bridges that cannot be mapped to any of the other bridge construction class codes.

5401.Name: Bridges, Conventional multiple span bridges
5401.Description: Bridges having multiple simple spans with each span being less than 500 feet. These bridges may be constructed of concrete, steel, or timber.

5402.Name: Bridges, Conventional continuous bridges
5402.Description: Bridges having continuous spans of less than 500 feet. These bridges may be constructed of concrete, steel, or timber.

5403.Name: Bridges, Major bridges
5403.Description: Bridges having individual spans of 500 feet or more. These bridges may be constructed of concrete or steel.

5404.Name: Bridges, Multispan simply supported CONCRETE
5404.Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges constructed of concrete and consisting of multiple simply supported spans, with individual span length less than 500 feet, spanning between consecutive piers and between abutments and piers.

5405.Name: Bridges, Multispan simply supported STEEL
5405.Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges constructed of steel and consisting of multiple simply supported spans, with individual span length less than 500 feet, spanning between consecutive piers and between abutments and piers.

5406.Name: Bridges, Single Span Bridge
5406.Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges constructed of steel or concrete and with a single span less than 500 feet spanning between abutments without intermediate piers. For single span bridges, the construction material does not matter.

5407.Name: Bridges, General Concrete
5407.Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges constructed of concrete with individual span length less than 500 feet, unknown number of spans, and unknown support conditions.

5408.Name: Bridges, General Steel
5408.Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges constructed of steel with individual span length less than 500 feet, unknown number of spans, and unknown support conditions.

5409.Name: Bridges, Multispan continuous CONCRETE
5409.Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges constructed of concrete and consisting of multiple continuously supported spans, with individual span length less than 500 feet, spanning between consecutive piers and between abutments and piers.

5410.Name: Bridges, Multispan continuous STEEL
5410.Description: Seismically or non-seismically designed highway bridges constructed of steel and consisting of multiple continuously supported spans, with individual span length less than 500 feet, spanning between consecutive piers and between abutments and piers.

5451.Name: Railways, General
5451.Description: General railways or railroads of unknown rail typology

5452.Name: Highways, General
5452.Description: General highways or pavements constructed of either concrete, asphalt, or gravel

5454.Name: Highways, Motorways
5454.Description: Motorway: restricted access major divided highway (i.e. freeway), normally with 2 or more running lanes plus emergency hard shoulder

5455.Name: Highways, Trunk road
5455.Description: Trunk: the most important roads in a country's system that aren't motorways (not necessarily be a divided highway)

5456.Name: Highways, Primary roads
5456.Description: Primary: the next most important roads in a country's system (often link larger towns)

5457.Name: Highways, Seconday roads
5457.Description: Secondary: the next most important roads in a country's system (often link towns)

5458.Name: Highways, Tertiary roads
5458.Description: Tertiary: the next most important roads in a country's system (often link smaller towns and villages)

5459.Name: Highways, Unclassified roads
5459.Description: Unclassified: the least important through roads in a country's system (often link villages and hamlets)

5460.Name: Highways, Residential roads
5460.Description: Residential: roads which serve as an access to housing, without function of connecting settlements. Often lined with housing.

5461.Name: Highways, Service road
5461.Description: Service: access roads to, or within an industrial estate, camp site, business park, car park etc.

5463.Name: Railways, light rail
5463.Description: Light rail: a higher-standard tram system, normally in its own right-of-way. Often reaches a considerable length (tens of kilometer)

5465.Name: Railways, Standard gauge
5465.Description: Rail: full sized passenger or freight trains in the standard gauge for the country or state

5466.Name: Railways, Subway
5466.Description: Subway: a city passenger underground rail service running mostly grade separated

5467.Name: Railways, Tram
5467.Description: Tram: one or two carriage rail vehicles, usually sharing motor road.

5501.Name: Dams, Concrete dams
5501.Description: Poured in place reinforced concrete dams.

5503.Name: Dam, General
5503.Description: Dams in general where material or type is unknown

5550.Name: Tunnels, Unknown Tunnel
5550.Description: Lined or unlined tunnels with unknown material and unknown method of construction, or other tunnels that cannot be mapped to any of the other tunnel construction class codes.

5551.Name: Tunnels, Alluvium tunnels
5551.Description: Tunnels that were drilled through unconsolidated sedimentary deposits and then typically lined with concrete.

5552.Name: Tunnels, Rock tunnels
5552.Description: Rock tunnels are lined or unlined tunnels that were drilled through rock.

5553.Name: Tunnels, Cut and cover tunnels
5553.Description: Tunnels that were constructed by cutting a trench, installing a liner, and then covering the liner with earth.

5554.Name: Tunnels, Rock Cut and Cover Tunnels
5554.Description: Lined or unlined rock tunnels constructed after excavating a trench and roofing over with an overhead support system.

5555.Name: Tunnels, Alluvial Cut and Cover Tunnels
5555.Description: Lined or unlined alluvium tunnels constructed after excavating a trench and roofing over with an overhead support system.

5556.Name: Tunnels, Alluvial Bored Tunnels
5556.Description: Lined or unlined tunnels constructed through alluvium soil using a boring machine.

5557.Name: Tunnels, Rock Bored Tunnels
5557.Description: Lined or unlined tunnels drilled through rock using a boring machine.

5600.Name: Tanks, Unknown Tanks
5600.Description: Storage tanks with an unknown material, unknown location, and unknown contents, or other unknowns that cannot be mapped to any of the other storage tank construction class codes.

5601.Name: Tanks, Underground Liquid Tanks
5601.Description: Storage tanks made of steel or concrete for holding liquids and located under the ground.

5602.Name: Tanks, Underground Solid Tanks
5602.Description: Storage tanks made of steel or concrete for holding solid material and located under the ground.

5603.Name: Tanks, On Ground Liquid Tanks
5603.Description: Storage tanks located on the ground surface for holding liquids with an unknown material of construction.

5604.Name: Tanks, On Ground Steel liquid Tanks
5604.Description: Storage tanks made of steel for holding liquids and located on the ground surface.

5605.Name: Tanks, On Ground Concrete liquid Tanks
5605.Description: Storage tanks made of concrete for holding liquids and located on the ground surface.

5606.Name: Tanks, On Ground Solid Tanks
5606.Description: Storage tanks located on the ground surface for holding solid material with an unknown material of construction.

5607.Name: Tanks, On Ground Steel solid Tanks
5607.Description: Storage tanks made of steel for holding solid material and located on the ground surface.

5608.Name: Tanks, On Ground Concrete solid Tanks
5608.Description: Storage tanks made of concrete for holding solid material and located on the ground surface.

5609.Name: Tanks, Elevated Liquid Tanks
5609.Description: Storage tanks located above the ground surface for holding liquids with an unknown material of construction.

5610.Name: Tanks, Elevated Steel liquid Tanks
5610.Description: Storage tanks made of steel for holding liquids and located above the ground surface.

5611.Name: Tanks, Elevated Concrete liquid Tanks
5611.Description: Storage tanks made of concrete for holding liquids and located above the ground surface.

5612.Name: Tanks, Elevated Solid Tanks
5612.Description: Storage tanks located above the ground surface for holding solid material with an unknown material of construction.

5613.Name: Tanks, Elevated Steel solid Tanks
5613.Description: Storage tanks made of steel for holding solid material and located above the ground surface.

5614.Name: Tanks, Elevated Concrete solid Tanks
5614.Description: Storage tanks made of concrete for holding solid material and located above the ground surface.

5650.Name: Pipelines, Unknown Pipeline
5650.Description: Pipelines with an unknown location and material, or other unknown pipelines that cannot be mapped to any of the other pipeline construction class codes.

5651.Name: Pipelines, General Underground Pipelines
5651.Description: Pipelines located under the surface of the ground with an unknown material of construction.

5652.Name: Pipelines, Underground Cast Iron Pipelines
5652.Description: Pipelines located under the surface of the ground and made of cast iron material.

5653.Name: Pipelines, Underground Asbestos Cement Pipelines
5653.Description: Pipelines located under the surface of the ground and made of asbestos-cement material.

5654.Name: Pipelines, Underground Concrete Pipelines
5654.Description: Pipelines located under the surface of the ground and made of concrete material.

5655.Name: Pipelines, Underground PVC Pipelines
5655.Description: Pipelines located under the surface of the ground and made of PVC material.

5656.Name: Pipelines, Underground Ductile Iron Pipelines
5656.Description: Pipelines located under the surface of the ground and made of ductile iron material.

5657.Name: Pipelines, General At Grade Pipelines
5657.Description: Pipelines located at the surface of the ground with an unknown material of construction.

5658.Name: Pipelines, At Grade Cast Iron Pipelines
5658.Description: Pipelines located at the surface of the ground and made of cast iron material.

5659.Name: Pipelines, At Grade Asbestos Cement Pipelines
5659.Description: Pipelines located at the surface of the ground and made of asbestos-cement material.

5660.Name: Pipelines, At Grade Concrete Pipelines
5660.Description: Pipelines located at the surface of the ground and made of concrete material.

5661.Name: Pipelines, At Grade PVC Pipelines
5661.Description: Pipelines located at the surface of the ground and made of PVC material.

5662.Name: Pipelines, At Grade Ductile Iron Pipelines
5662.Description: Pipelines located at the surface of the ground and made of ductile iron material.

5702.Name: Chimneys, Concrete chimneys
5702.Description: Reinforced concrete chimneys over 30 feet high.

5751.Name: Towers, Electrical transmission conventional
5751.Description: Steel towers under 100 feet high designed to hold up electrical transmission lines.

5752.Name: Towers, Electrical transmission major
5752.Description: Steel towers over 100 feet high designed to hold up electrical transmission lines.

5753.Name: Towers, Broadcast towers
5753.Description: Steel towers designed to carry radio, TV, or cell phone transmission equipment.

5754.Name: Towers, Observation towers
5754.Description: Elevated towers designed for people to look out of, such as airport control or fire observation towers.

5755.Name: Towers, Offshore towers
5755.Description: Offshore towers are towers with a platform that are anchored to the ground under the ocean.

5756.Name: Distribution Circuits
5756.Description: Distribution circuits designed to carry radio, TV, or cell phone transmission equipment.

5801.Name: Equipment, Residential equipment
5801.Description: Residential furnishings including furniture and appliances.

5802.Name: Equipment, Office equipment
5802.Description: Office furniture, file cabinets, PCs, etc.

5803.Name: Equipment, Electrical equipment
5803.Description: Non-high tech electrical equipment other than electrical equipment included as part of the function of the building.

5804.Name: Equipment, Mechanical equipment
5804.Description: All equipment not otherwise classified in a building.

5805.Name: Equipment, High-technology equipment
5805.Description: Sensitive equipment easily damaged by shaking.

5806.Name: Equipment, Trains, trucks, airplanes etc.
5806.Description: Any type of train, truck, or airplane.

5807.Name: Equipment, Thermal Power Plant
5807.Description: Thermal power plants are energy centers that convert heat energy into electrical energy. In Japan, heat is usually generated by fuel, coal, or nuclear. Plants typically include components, such as boilers (or reactors), gas turbines, pumps, generators, cooling towers, power transmission lines, substations, transformers, bushings, circuit breakers/switches, waste management facilities, and building structures supporting operation of the plant or for administrative purposes.

5850.Name: Automobiles, Unknown HAZUS
5850.Description: Typically a four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation. Use this code for unknown automobiles in general or for HAZUS unknown classification.

5851.Name: Automobiles, Personal
5851.Description: Typically a four-wheeled personal automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation.

5852.Name: Automobiles, Dealers
5852.Description: Typically a four-wheeled dealers (part of the fleet) automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation.

5853.Name: Automobiles, 4 Wheeler
5853.Description: Typically a four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation.

5854.Name: Automobiles, 2 Wheeler
5854.Description: Typically a two-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation; may include a side car with a third wheel.

5856.Name: Motorcycles, Small
5856.Description: A two-wheeled or three-wheeled vehicle with a maximum design speed of not more than 50 km/h

5857.Name: Motorcycles, Large
5857.Description: Mopeds, Motorcycles, Motor Tricycles and Quadricycles with a maximum design speed of more than 50 km/h

5858.Name: Automobiles, M1
5858.Description: Vehicles designed and constructed for the carriage of passengers and comprising no more than eight seats in addition to the driver’s seat, and having a maximum mass (“technically permissible maximum laden mass”) not exceeding 3.5 tons

5859.Name: Buses, M2 + M3
5859.Description: Vehicles designed and constructed for the carriage of passengers, comprising more than eight seats in addition to the driver’s seat

5860.Name: Automobiles, M1 Low cost
5860.Description: M1 type vehicle with value lower than average M1 car.

5861.Name: Automobiles, M1 High cost
5861.Description: M1 type vehicle with value higher than average M1 car.

5862.Name: Automobiles, M1 Large fleet
5862.Description: Typically a fleet from 51 up to 100 vehicles of M1 type.

5863.Name: Automobiles, M1 Mid-size fleet
5863.Description: Typically a fleet from 21 up to 50 vehicles of M1 type.

5864.Name: Automobiles, M1 Small fleet
5864.Description: Typically a fleet with up to 20 vehicles of M1 type.

5865.Name: Cargo, N
5865.Description: Power-driven vehicles having at least four wheels and used for the carriage of goods

5868.Name: Mobile industrial machines, S
5868.Description: Self-propelled industrial machines. Trailer industrial machines. Tractor trailer industrial machines.

5870.Name: Cars GEC, unknown GEC
5870.Description: Typically a four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation.

5871.Name: Cars GEC, Compact
5871.Description: Typically a four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation with passenger and cargo volume between 100 cu. ft. (2830 l) and 109 cu. ft. (3110 l)

5872.Name: Cars GEC, Large
5872.Description: Typically a four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation with passenger and cargo volume higher than 120 cu. ft. (3400 l)

5873.Name: Cars GEC, Mid-Size
5873.Description: Typically a four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation with passenger and cargo volume between 110 cu. ft. (3110 l) and 119 cu. ft. (3395 l)

5874.Name: Cars GEC, Pick-Up & Trucks and SUV

5875.Name: Cars GEC, Sub-Compact
5875.Description: Typically a four-wheeled automotive vehicle designed for passenger transportation with passenger and cargo volume less than 99 cu. ft. (2830 l)

5900.Name: Marine Craft, Pleasure Boats & Yachts
5900.Description: Typically privately-owned boats that can be used for recreation, fishing, or cruising. This description is meant to exclude commercial vessels, such as cargo ships or tugboats. Use this construction code if the boat power/sail classification is unknown.

5901.Name: Marine Craft, Pleasure Boats & Yachts - Power Boats
5901.Description: A pleasure boat that is powered only by a motor (no sails).

5902.Name: Marine Craft, Pleasure Boats & Yachts - Sail Boats
5902.Description: A pleasure boat that is capable of being powered by wind through the use of sails. Boats that have both sails and a motor should be modeled under this code.

5951.Name: Miscellaneous, Railway Property
5951.Description: Railway properties are composed of major components of railway systems, which include railway stations, railway tunnels, railway bridges, railway tracks, and cables along the tracks but excluding trains.

5952.Name: Miscellaneous, Pumping Station
5952.Description: Pumping stations are structures with mechanical devices that are used typically when a fluid material must be raised from a low point to a point of higher elevation, or where the topography prevents downhill gravity flow.

5953.Name: Miscellaneous, Compressor stations
5953.Description: Compressor stations are structures with mechanical devices that are used for increasing the pressure of a gas by mechanically decreasing its volume.

5954.Name: Miscellaneous, Cranes
5954.Description: A machine for raising, shifting, and lowering heavy weights by means of a projecting swinging arm or with the hoisting apparatus supported on an overhead track.

5955.Name: Miscellaneous, Conveyor systems
5955.Description: Devices used for moving loose material (typically on a belt, on rollers, or in an auger).

5956.Name: Miscellaneous, Canals
5956.Description: An artificial waterway of any depth used for draining or irrigating land or for navigation.

5957.Name: Miscellaneous, Earth retaining structures
5957.Description: Earth retaining structures taller than 20 feet high.

5958.Name: Miscellaneous, Waterfront structures
5958.Description: Wharves or docks built next to the shore of navigable waters so that ships may receive and discharge cargo and passengers or walls of artificially enclosed basins into which vessels are brought for inspection and repair.

5959.Name: Miscellaneous, Transit Warehouse
5959.Description: Transit warehouses often refer to distribution centers that temporarily store various commodities for further distribution, including wholesale stores. The commodities can be light (e.g., food, drug, light fabrication of clothing, high technology electricals) and heavy (e.g., heavy construction machineries). Warehouses are typically one story steel frame or SRC (steel reinforced concrete) construction with high ceilings. Most of the commodities are well packed and can be stacked during storage.

5960.Name: Miscellaneous, Marine Hull
5960.Description: Marine hull insurance covers the hull and machinery of a vessel. Specific ports or docks include loading or unloading (port risk), under construction (builders risk), and repair (repairing risk).

5961.Name: Miscellaneous, Treatment plant
5961.Description: Treatment plants are structures and sites for the treatment of potable water or wastewater

6051.Name: Marine Cargo, Carpool
6051.Description: Open areas close to harbors where thousands of cars are gridded before being shipped on Personal Car Carriers (PCCs).

6052.Name: Marine Cargo, General and Containerized Cargo
6052.Description: Cubicles 8 feet in width, 8.5 feet in height, and 20 or 40 feet in length in which commodities are packed. Cubicles are usually stacked on ships, trains, or airplanes for long-distance transportation.

6053.Name: Marine Cargo, Heavy Cargo
6053.Description: Heavy cargos are usually heavy machinery that cannot be fit into a standard container, such as jack-up and semi-submersible rigs, dredging equipment, luxury yachts, offshore production modules and sub-sea structures, construction machinery, container cranes and harbor equipment, and complete factories. Vessels used for this type of cargo are usually semi-submersible heavy lift ships, conventional heavy lift ships, tow barges and dockships. Heavy cargo is sometimes containerized.

6054.Name: Marine Cargo, Refrigerated Cargo
6054.Description: Refrigerated cargo is similar to general containerized cargo, but with additional cooling equipment to keep commodities fresh. Commodities are commonly fruits and frozen goods. This type of containerized cargo requires an external source of power to maintain a temperature-controlled environment.

6055.Name: Marine Cargo, Dry Bulk Cargo
6055.Description: Dry bulk cargo refers to bare solid materials, such as coal, metal ore, lumber, and grains.

6056.Name: Marine Cargo, Liquid Bulk Cargo
6056.Description: Liquid bulk cargo refers to bare liquid material, such as oil, liquefied natural gas, and liquid chemicals. Liquid bulk cargo is generally stored in tank farms on shore.

6101.Name: Marine Cargo, Combustible: Carpool
6101.Description: Open areas close to harbors where thousands of cars are gridded before being shipped on Personal Car Carriers (PCCs).

6102.Name: Marine Cargo, Combustible: General and Containerized
6102.Description: Cubicles 8 feet in width, 8.5 feet in height, and 20 or 40 feet in length in which commodities are packed. Cubicles are usually stacked on ships, trains, or airplanes for long-distance transportation.

6103.Name: Marine Cargo, Combustible: Heavy Cargo
6103.Description: Heavy cargos are usually heavy machinery that cannot be fit into a standard container, such as jack-up and semi-submersible rigs, dredging equipment, luxury yachts, offshore production modules and sub-sea structures, construction machinery, container cranes and harbor equipment, and complete factories. Vessels used for this type of cargo are usually semi-submersible heavy lift ships, conventional heavy lift ships, tow barges, and dockships. Heavy cargo is sometimes containerized.

6104.Name: Marine Cargo, Combustible: Refrigerated Cargo
6104.Description: Refrigerated cargo is similar to general containerized cargo, but with additional cooling equipment to keep commodities fresh. Commodities are commonly fruits and frozen goods. This type of containerized cargo requires an external source of power to maintain a temperature-controlled environment.

6105.Name: Marine Cargo, Combustible: Dry Bulk Cargo
6105.Description: Dry bulk cargo refers to bare solid materials, such as coal, metal ore, lumber, and grains.

6106.Name: Marine Cargo, Combustible: Liquid Bulk Cargo
6106.Description: Liquid bulk cargo refers to bare liquid material, such as oil, liquefied natural gas, and liquid chemicals. Liquid bulk cargo is generally stored in tank farms on shore.

6151.Name: Marine Cargo, Non-Combustible: Carpool
6151.Description: Open areas close to harbors where thousands of cars are gridded before being shipped on Personal Car Carriers (PCCs).

6152.Name: Marine Cargo, Non-Combustible: General and Container
6152.Description: Cubicles 8 feet in width, 8.5 feet in height, and 20 or 40 feet in length in which commodities are packed. Cubicles are usually stacked on ships, trains, or airplanes for long-distance transportation.

6153.Name: Marine Cargo, Non-Combustible: Heavy Cargo
6153.Description: Heavy cargos are usually heavy machinery that cannot be fit into a standard container, such as jack-up and semi-submersible rigs, dredging equipment, luxury yachts, offshore production modules and sub-sea structures, construction machinery, container cranes and harbor equipment, and complete factories. Vessels used for this type of cargo are usually semi-submersible heavy lift ships, conventional heavy lift ships, tow barges, and dockships. Heavy cargo is sometimes containerized.

6154.Name: Marine Cargo, Non-Combustible: Refrigerated Cargo
6154.Description: Refrigerated cargo is similar to general containerized cargo, but with additional cooling equipment to keep commodities fresh. Commodities are commonly fruits and frozen goods. This type of containerized cargo requires an external source of power to maintain a temperature-controlled environment.

6155.Name: Marine Cargo, Non-Combustible: Dry Bulk Cargo
6155.Description: Dry bulk cargo refers to bare solid materials, such as coal, metal ore, lumber, and grains.

6156.Name: Marine Cargo, Non-Combustible: Liquid Bulk Cargo
6156.Description: Liquid bulk cargo refers to bare liquid material, such as oil, liquefied natural gas, and liquid chemicals. Liquid bulk cargo is generally stored in tank farms on shore.

7000.Name: Offshore, Unknown
7000.Description: A structure that is anchored to the ground under the ocean. Platform construction class is unknown.

7001.Name: Offshore, Caisson
7001.Description: Caisson platforms use large diameter caissons to support a single well completion with a minimal deck. The deck is capable of supporting limited production, control equipment, and navigational aids. Caisson platform completions are limited to water depths of 100 feet or less.

7002.Name: Offshore, Compliant Tower
7002.Description: Compliant Towers consist of narrow, flexible towers and piled foundations that can support a conventional deck for drilling and production operations. Unlike fixed platforms, Compliant Towers withstand large lateral forces by sustaining significant lateral deflections and are usually used in water depths between 1,000 and 2,000 feet.

7003.Name: Offshore, Fixed Jacket Platform
7003.Description: Fixed platforms consist of jackets (a tall vertical section made of tubular steel members supported by piles driven into the seabed) with a deck placed on top, providing space for crew quarters, a drilling rig, and production facilities. Fixed platforms are economically feasible for installation in water depths up to 1,500 feet.

7004.Name: Offshore, Jack-up
7004.Description: Jackups are platforms that can be jacked up above the sea using legs that can be lowered like jacks. These platforms, used in relatively low depths, are designed to move from place to place and then anchor themselves by deploying the jack-like legs.

7005.Name: Offshore, Mini Tension Leg Platform
7005.Description: Mini Tension Leg Platforms (MTLP) are floating platforms of relatively low cost developed for production of smaller deepwater reserves that would be uneconomic to produce using more conventional deepwater production systems. They can also be used as a utility, satellite, or early production platform for larger deepwater discoveries.

7007.Name: Offshore, Semi Submersible Floating Production
7007.Description: Semi-submersible floating production platforms have legs of sufficient buoyancy to cause the structure to float, but weight sufficient to keep the structure upright. These rigs can be moved from place to place and ballasted up or down by altering the amount of flooding in buoyancy tanks. They are generally anchored by cable anchors during drilling operations, though they can also be kept in place by the use of dynamic positioning. Semi-submersibles can be used in depths from 200 to 6,000 feet.

7008.Name: Offshore, Drill Ship
7008.Description: Drill ships are maritime vessels that have been fitted with drilling apparatuses. They are most often used for exploratory drilling of new oil or gas wells in deep water, but can also be used for scientific drilling. They are often built on modified tanker hulls and outfitted with dynamic positioning systems to maintain their position over a well. Drill ships are able to drill in water depths of over 6,500 feet.

7009.Name: Offshore, SPAR Floating Production System
7009.Description: SPARs consist of a large diameter single vertical cylinder supporting a deck. They have typical fixed platform topsides (surface decks with drilling and production equipment), three types of risers (production, drilling, and export), and hulls moored with taut caternary systems of six to 20 lines anchored into the seafloor. SPARs are generally used in water depths up to 3,000 feet.

7010.Name: Offshore, Submersible Production System
7010.Description: Floating vessels, usually used as mobile offshore drilling units (MODUs), that are supported primarily on large pontoon-like structures submerged below the sea surface. The operating decks are elevated 100 or more feet above the pontoons on large steel columns. Once on the desired location, this type of structure is slowly flooded until it rests on the sea floor. After the well is completed, the water is pumped out of the buoyancy tanks, and the vessel is refloated and towed to the next location. Submersibles operate in relatively shallow water, since they must rest on the seafloor.

7011.Name: Offshore, Underwater Production Units, Completion
7011.Description: Subsea Systems range from single subsea wells producing to a nearby platform, FPS, or TLP to multiple wells producing through a manifold and pipeline system to a distant production facility. These systems are presently used in water depths greater than 5,000 feet.

7012.Name: Offshore, Tension Leg Platform
7012.Description: Tension Leg Platforms (TLPs) consist of a floating structure held in place by vertical, tensioned tendons connected to the sea floor by pile-secured templates. Tensioned tendons provide for the use of a TLP in a broad water depth range with limited vertical motion. Larger TLPs have been successfully deployed in water depths approaching 4,000 feet.

7014.Name: Offshore Renewables - General
7014.Description: Covers offshore wind, hydrgogen, ocean wave, tidal, thermal and salinity gradient technologies and floating solar PV. It is preferred to separate these items if possible.

7015.Name: Offshore Wind - General
7015.Description: Covers Turbines, cables and substations. It is preferred to separate these items if possible.

7016.Name: Offshore Wind - Turbine
7016.Description: Offshore wind turbine. Key Loc fields to define the turbine are: Capacity and FoundationType.

7017.Name: Offshore Wind - Cable - General
7017.Description: Covers Infield, Export, Transmission, and Interconnector cables. It is preferred to separate these items if possible.

7018.Name: Offshore Wind - Cable - Infield
7018.Description: Array cables connect wind turbines to each other and to the offshore substation. Also called 'inter-aray cables'.

7019.Name: Offshore Wind - Cable - Export
7019.Description: Export cables transfer power from offshore wind farms to connect to an onshore grid network typically via intermediate AC substations or DC converters. In some instances export cables can connect to an offshore grid system, as seen in Germany, or alternative end-use such as oil and gas platforms or industrial facility.

7020.Name: Offshore Wind - Cable - Transmission
7020.Description: Transmission cables connect an offshore shared platform to the onshore substation/converter.

7021.Name: Offshore Wind - Cable - Interconnector
7021.Description: Interconnectors are submarine cables that transfer electricity between two grids. They can be both domestic or international. 4C Offshore interconnectors database also contains ‘oil and gas electrification’ projects, which refer to subsea cables that powers oil and gas platform from shore.

7022.Name: Offshore Wind - Onshore Substation
7022.Description: Generally, the onshore substation will consist of switchgear, metering, transformers and associated plant. The onshore substation may also have reactive compensation equipment, depending on the network operator requirements and the design of the offshore network

7023.Name: Offshore Wind - Offshore Substation
7023.Description: Offshore substations are the systems that collect and export the power generated by turbines through specialized submarine cables. Can sometimes comprise HVDC conversion. Reactive (power) compensation platforms/stations can be included in this coding also.

8031.Name: Crops, Vegetables and melons, Leafy or stem vegetables
8031.Description: Crops, Vegetables and melons, Leafy or stem vegetables

8032.Name: Crops, Vegetables and melons, Fruit-bearing vegetables
8032.Description: Crops, Vegetables and melons, Fruit-bearing vegetables

8033.Name: Crops, Vegetables and melons, Root, bulb, or tuberous vegetables
8033.Description: Crops, Vegetables and melons, Root, bulb, or tuberous vegetables

8034.Name: Crops, Vegetables and melons, Mushrooms and truffles
8034.Description: Crops, Vegetables and melons, Mushrooms and truffles

8051.Name: Crops, Fruits and nuts, Tropical and subtropical fruits
8051.Description: Crops, Fruits and nuts, Tropical and subtropical fruits

8052.Name: Crops, Fruits and nuts, Citrus fruits
8052.Description: Crops, Fruits and nuts, Citrus fruits

8055.Name: Crops, Fruits and nuts, Pome fruits and stone fruits
8055.Description: Crops, Fruits and nuts, Pome fruits and stone fruits

8090.Name: Crops, Root/tuber crops with high starch or inulin content, Unknown
8090.Description: Crops, Root/tuber crops with high starch or inulin content, Unknown

8091.Name: Crops, Root/tuber crops with high starch or inulin content, Potatoes
8091.Description: Crops, Root/tuber crops with high starch or inulin content, Potatoes

8092.Name: Crops, Root/tuber crops with high starch or inulin content, Sweet potatoes
8092.Description: Crops, Root/tuber crops with high starch or inulin content, Sweet potatoes

8093.Name: Crops, Root/tuber crops with high starch or inulin content, Cassava Yams
8093.Description: Crops, Root/tuber crops with high starch or inulin content, Cassava Yams

8094.Name: Crops, Root/tuber crops with high starch or inulin content, Other
8094.Description: Crops, Root/tuber crops with high starch or inulin content, Other

8100.Name: Crops, Beverage and spice crops, Unknown
8100.Description: Crops, Beverage and spice crops, Unknown

8101.Name: Crops, Beverage and spice crops, Beverage crops
8101.Description: Crops, Beverage and spice crops, Beverage crops

8102.Name: Crops, Beverage and spice crops, Spice crops
8102.Description: Crops, Beverage and spice crops, Spice crops

8103.Name: Crops, Beverage and spice crops, Other
8103.Description: Crops, Beverage and spice crops, Other

8140.Name: Crops, Other crops, Grasses and other fodder crops
8140.Description: Crops, Other crops, Grasses and other fodder crops

8142.Name: Crops, Other crops, Medicinal, aromatic, pesticidal, or similar crops
8142.Description: Crops, Other crops, Medicinal, aromatic, pesticidal, or similar crops

8312.Name: Livestock, Camels and camelids, Llamas and alpacas
8312.Description: Livestock, Camels and camelids, Llamas and alpacas

8320.Name: Livestock, Other animals, Deer, elk, reindeer

8401.Name: Forestry, Closed forest, Mainly evergreen forest
8401.Description: Forestry, Closed forest, Mainly evergreen forest - the canopy is never without green foliage, but individual trees may shed their leaves (e.g. Sumatra, Atrato Valley (Colombia), Atlantic slopes of Costa Rica, Amazon Basin).

8402.Name: Forestry, Closed forest, Mainly deciduous forest
8402.Description: Forestry, Closed forest, Mainly deciduous forest - majority of trees shed their foliage simultaneously in connection to unfavourable season (e.g. North and South America, Southern slopes of the Himalayas and Europe)

8403.Name: Forestry, Closed forest, Extremely xeromorphic forest
8403.Description: Forestry, Closed forest, Extremely xeromorphic forest - dense stands of trees, composed by species such as bottle or tuft rees with succulent leaves (e.g. thorn forest in Southwestern North America and Southwestern Africa)

8404.Name: Forestry, Woodland, Mainly evergreen woodland
8404.Description: Forestry, Woodland, Mainly evergreen woodland - the canopy is never without green foliage, but individual trees may shed their leaves (e.g. Mediterranean Basin).

8405.Name: Forestry, Woodland, Mainly deciduous woodland
8405.Description: Forestry, Woodland, Mainly deciduous woodland - majority of trees shed their foliage simultaneously in connection to unfavourable season (e.g. Southern California and American Southeast, Mediterranean Basin)

8406.Name: Forestry, Woodland, Extremely xeromorphic woodland
8406.Description: Forestry, Woodland, Extremely xeromorphic woodland - dense stands of trees, composed by species such as bottle or tuft rees with succulent leaves (e.g. Southwestern North America and Southwestern Africa)

8407.Name: Forestry, Scrub, Mainly evergreen scrub
8407.Description: Forestry, Scrub, Mainly evergreen scrub - the canopy is never without green foliage, but individual species may shed their leaves (e.g. Mediterranean dwarf palm shrubland, Chaparral shrubland in California or Hawaiian tree fern thicket).

8408.Name: Forestry, Scrub, Mainly deciduous scrub
8408.Description: Forestry, Scrub, Mainly deciduous scrub - majority of scrub shed their foliage simultaneously in connection to unfavourable season (e.g. peat mosses in Scotland)

8409.Name: Forestry, Scrub, Extremely xeromorphic (subdesert) shrubland
8409.Description: Forestry, Scrub, Extremely xeromorphic (subdesert) shrubland - very open stands of shrubs, often composed by vegetation with green branches without leaves, some of them with thorns (e.g. mulga scrub in Australia).

8410.Name: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Mainly evergreen dwarf-scrub
8410.Description: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Mainly evergreen dwarf-scrub - mostly dense dwarf scrub evergreen dominating the landscape (e.g. East Mediterranean mountains).

8411.Name: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Mainly deciduous scrub
8411.Description: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Mainly deciduous scrub - majority of vegetation shed their foliage simultaneously in connection to unfavourable season (e.g. Sierra Nevada in California )

8412.Name: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Extremely xeromorphic dwarf-shrubland
8412.Description: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Extremely xeromorphic dwarf-shrubland - more or less open formations consisting of dwarf-shrubs or succulent species (e.g. Australia).

8413.Name: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Tundra
8413.Description: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Tundra - slowly growing, low formations, consisting mainly of dwarf-shrubs beyond the subpolar tree line (e.g. Alaska, Northern Canada, Greenland, Norway, Finland and Siberia).

8414.Name: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Mossy bog formations with dwarf-shrub
8414.Description: Forestry, Dwarf-scrub and related communities, Mossy bog formations with dwarf-shrub - peat accumulations formed mainly by mosses which generally cover the surface as well (e.g. Western Siberian Lowlands in Russia).

8415.Name: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Tall graminoid vegetation
8415.Description: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Tall graminoid vegetation - Mostly composed by tall grasslands with heights of over 2 m. Forbs can be presented but their coverage is less than 50% (e.g. Northeast Bolivia, African savannah and upper Nile Valley).

8416.Name: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Medium tall grassland
8416.Description: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Medium tall grassland - Mostly composed by grasslands with heights between 0.5 and 2 m. Forbs can be presented but their coverage is less than 50% (e.g. Sahel region in Africa, Eastern Kansas, glasslands in New Zealand)

8417.Name: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Short grassland
8417.Description: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Short grassland - Mostly composed by grasslands with heights below 0.5 m. Forbs can be presented but their coverage is less than 50% (e.g. alpine regions of Kenya, Colombia and Venezuela).

8418.Name: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Forb vegetation
8418.Description: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Forb vegetation - the plant community if mostly composed by forbs (more than 50%). (e.g. Sonoran Desert)

8419.Name: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Hydromorphic fresh-water vegetation
8419.Description: Forestry, Herbaceous vegetation, Hydromorphic fresh-water vegetation - mostly composed by aquatic plants that are structurally supported by water, in wet or flooded regions most of the year (e.g. Amazon Basin)
